title: UK and Turkey join forces against people smuggling gangs
body:
T he UK and Turkey have struck a new deal to address the surge in illegal migration, which will focus on co-ordinated actions to "disrupt and dismantle people smuggling gangs".

Part of the deal is the establishment of a new operational "centre of excellence" by the Turkish National Police.

Supported by the UK, the centre will focus on addressing organised immigration crime by sharing intelligence more fully and more quickly between the two nations.

Home Secretary Suella Braverman (Jordan Pettitt/PA) / PA Wire

Home Secretary Suella Braverman said: "As I've made clear, we must do everything we can to smash the people smuggling gangs and stop the boats.

"Our partnership with Turkey, a close friend and ally, will enable our law enforcement agencies to work together on this international problem and tackle the small boat supply chain."

Immigration minister Robert Jenrick said: "We will be intensively sharing intelligence, people and technology to disrupt and dismantle people smuggling gangs and the manufacture and supply of materials which enable small boat crossings.

"Having met our partners in Europe, North Africa and indeed Turkey recently, I've seen first-hand the benefits our increased co-operation has on stopping the boats.

"I am determined that the UK is a leading force in tackling illegal migration and a partner to all those allies who share our determination to defeat it."

Migrants have begun arriving on the Bibby Stockholm barge docked in Portland off the coast of Dorset (James Manning/PA) / PA Wire

The new operational centre will aim to strengthen collaboration between the National Crime Agency and Home Office Intelligence staff based in Turkey and their Turkish counterparts.

The UK will also deploy more officers in Turkey to collaborate on joint operations to disrupt criminal gangs facilitating illegal journeys.

According to the Home Office, the export of small boats and boat parts across Europe to facilitate illegal crossings to the UK is a vital element of people smugglers' tactics with hundreds of small boats and boat parts thought to be transported each year.

The deal comes after Mr Jenrick's visit to Turkey last month, where he visited the Turkish-Bulgarian Border Check Point at Kapikule – the largest and busiest border crossing point in Europe.

The announcement is also one of a series the Government will be making as part of its "stop the boats" week.

On Monday, after weeks of delays, the first 15 asylum seekers boarded the Bibby Stockholm barge.

Around 50 people were expected to move onboard the giant vessel, docked in Portland Port in Dorset, but around 20 were granted a last-minute reprieve after legal challenges.

taxonomy_info.explanation: The article explicitly names Suella Braverman as "Home Secretary" and quotes her, confirming both her name and her role as a political office holder.

reasoning.identity_verification_and_presence: The article explicitly names "Home Secretary Suella Braverman" and includes a direct quote attributed to her. The name matches the Wikidata entity name, and the title "Home Secretary" aligns with the Wikidata position held (Home Secretary, 2022‑10‑25 to 2023‑11‑13). Despite the article’s apparent 2026 date, the reference to her as Home Secretary is consistent with the entity’s known role at the time of the quoted statement. No other individual with a similar name and conflicting key details is mentioned, so the identity match is clear.
reasoning.statement_assessment: Suella Braverman is directly quoted: "Home Secretary Suella Braverman said: 'As I've made clear, we must do everything we can to smash the people smuggling gangs and stop the boats...'" This is a clear instance of the entity making a statement.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for the Home Secretary to issue a statement on migration and people‑smuggling policy, as this falls squarely within the remit of the Home Office.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: The only potential inconsistency is the article’s 2026 timestamp, while Wikidata records her tenure as Home Secretary ending in 2023‑11‑13. This suggests a possible misdating or outdated reference in the article, but it does not affect the identity match or the fact that she is quoted. No other contradictions regarding identity or role are present.

reasoning.identity_verification_and_presence: The article explicitly names "Immigration minister Robert Jenrick" and quotes him. The name matches the Wikidata entity (Robert Jenrick). The title "Immigration minister" aligns with his known role as Minister of State for Immigration (a ministerial position dealing with immigration). No other individual named Robert Jenrick is mentioned, and the context (UK‑Turkey migration deal) matches the political domain of the Wikidata profile. Therefore the entity is present and identifiable.
reasoning.statement_assessment: The article contains a direct quote attributed to him: "We will be intensively sharing intelligence..." and other statements. Thus, the entity is making statements in the article.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for the UK Immigration minister to speak about intelligence sharing and anti‑smuggling measures in the context of a UK‑Turkey migration agreement. The statements are consistent with the responsibilities of his ministerial role.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions are found between the article’s description of Robert Jenrick and the Wikidata profile. The only minor discrepancy is the article’s use of the generic title "Immigration minister" versus the specific title "Minister of State for Immigration" in Wikidata; this is a common shorthand and does not indicate a different person.
